instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
magsafe green led and red led 
no fan no power

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
threads.message: There must be some voltages on the board; please post.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
threads.message: can you tell me specifically which rye should I measure thanks?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
threads.message:
Exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?
Test w/and w/o battery connected.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
threads.message:
Diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Don't forget to remove charger and battery; also allow 10-15s before checking in diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
threads.message:
I asked about diode mode and I don't know what you've really replied.
Read about checking in diode mode here:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

Still no reply about <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> voltage.

BTW, do not write end "V" after diode mode reading!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
threads.message:
diode mode 
battery magsafe not connected 
0,003

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook pro no power
threads.message: If you get the same diode mode reading at L7310/20/30, lift the coils one side (one by one) and check when (if) short disappears from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
